B00005JKZT|5.0|This is \\"storytelling\\" and \\"storyseeing\\" of the highest order. We were all blown away by Part I and left the theater asking how Parts II and III could measure up. Would there be a let down? Was all the budget used up on Part I? (They had to know we would all go see Part II anyway.) Well, Part II answers those questions. If anything, this movie is more satisfying, more detailed and more expensive than the first and the perfect set up for the final part of the Trilogy.<br />The action is intense and unrelenting, making room for digital effects to be a part of almost every scene, but nothing gets in the way of the tale.  The care and detail show up everywhere. When the digital effects start flowing in the battles, focus now and then on the corners of the screen. There are even small subplots of action there.<br />You literally could not have made this movie five years ago--unless you would have settled for a Gollum puppet or some man in a Gollum costume. The poor creature is done just about perfectly and actually looks the best in the close up shots. Here, what I saw on the screen matched the vision that I had as I read the book.<br />Some slight liberties were taken with the storyline, but its not a bad thing in the context of what they faced in making a movie out of such a long book. I do recommend that you again read or watch \\"Fellowship\\" before you go so you can more easily jump into the full storyline and remember all of characters. Be warned that Part II starts with no summary review of the events we saw in last year's film--it just continues.<br />As a small negative, some of the dialog (like that of Treebeard) seemed overly distorted and a little hard to follow. Thus, I missed a few of the jokes. (Yes, parts are funny, even in the midst of battle.) Maybe it was due to where I sat in the theater, maybe it was due to my failing old \\"rock concert\\" ears --but maybe that's just the way Ents talk!<br />Go and enjoy a really great film!
B00004STPT|5.0|This soundtrack should have won the Academy Award for best score, not Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. This score was far more superior and is one of the best I have heard in a long time. The highlights of the score are the mega battle scenes represented in &quot;The Battle&quot; and &quot;Barbarian Horde&quot;, which is the best cue on the entire soundtrack. Here Zimmer uses his synthesizer banks and fuses them with a massive and powerful symphony orchestra. The horns have most of the thematic content along with blasting rhythms and sheer power from the orchestra. Parts of these cues sound like Gustav Holst's &quot;Mars&quot; from &quot;The Planets&quot; which makes sense because Mars was the Roman God of War. The actual main theme is heard in &quot;Earth&quot; and is a mysterious, slightly ominous and sorrowful theme played wonderfully on the cello and trumpet. The orchestral might is featured in several of the other tracks too, including &quot;Patricide&quot;, which is a very dramatic track, &quot;The Might of Rome&quot;, &quot;Slaves to Rome&quot;, &quot;Honor Him&quot;, and &quot;Now We Are Free&quot;. Great choral work is present in the ominous and dark track &quot;Am I Not Merciful?&quot; The vocals by Lisa Gerrard are incredible and truly give the film its heart and soul with her dreamy and moody vocals as in &quot;The Wheat&quot;, &quot;Sorrow&quot;, &quot;The Emperor Is Dead&quot;, &quot;Elysium&quot;, and &quot;Now We Are Free&quot;. Some of the other instruments that are found are guitars and the duduk, which is an ancient Armenian instrument, that is present in &quot;To Zucchabar&quot;. In the end, the result of all of the tracks is breathtaking. The Lyndhurst Orchestra does a phenomenal job in performing the music and it sounds simply outstanding in the film and by itself. A must have soundtrack that everyone should own.
B00006CXXU|5.0|Christina Aguilera's previous releases were anything but groundbreaking. She did manage to mark the industry, though, with her powerful voice, although her bubblegum-pop sound didn't complement her voice as well as it should have. She had an amazing following regardless.<br />\\"Stripped\\" is her first real album in 3 years. She has managed to hold her fans and basically stall with a Christmas album, a re-release of her self-titled debut in Spanish, and various other small projects. But in 2002, controversy began to surround the first single off of her long-awaited album. \\"Dirrty\\" hit the airwaves and was a hit from the moment it begun--but the video (which was risque but very enjoyable and protrayed the image the song conveyed very well) sparked differences of opinion. Carson Daly coined it as \\"soft-core porn\\" and Parade magazine pointedly called it \\"sick\\". The video was either an ingenious marketing ploy or the result of Christina (oh, excuse me: X-Tina) deciding to shift into adult territory. Probably both.<br />\\"Stripped\\" is simply amazing. Christina seems to dive in headfirst, shrugging off all negative press she may get. It gives her album a strong feel, and strength is what it is all about. The main point of the album was to show how Christina really is: stripped of the gloss of the pop industry, and, underneath it all, she is one amazing singer.<br />Her album shows talent in every word, in every beat. The first major change you may notice: Christina shares credit on most of the songs on the album. This embeds her own, pure emotion into each of the songs. Even the songs she didn't write seem to be more honest than ever before. Those frightened by the \\"Dirrty\\" image need not worry: the rest of the album doesn't reflect that single at all. In fact, there is no repitition on this album whatsoever.<br />Most pop is the definition of repitition these days (prime example: Avril Lavigne), but each track on \\"Stripped\\" is completely, totally, 100% different from the onebefore. Christina shows her vocal gift, changing from her robust, hip-hop \\"Dirrty\\" image to a personal, slower \\"I'm OK\\". She belts out gospel notes on \\"Impossible\\" (composed by Alicia Keys) and \\"Soar\\", an inspirational gospel song. \\"Can't Hold Us Down\\" (featuring Lil' Kim) is a girl-power anthem with an R&B beat which shows a stronger Christina. \\"Fighter\\" is a sizzling, heavy rock song. Christina's voice is as powerful as ever, commanding the electric guitar. \\"Cruz\\" is a song about a personal journey, definitely a highlight, and \\"Beautiful\\" is a trademark ballad. Although Christina didn't compose this song, she sings it almost as if it were an autobiography. \\"Make Over\\" is also one of the standout tracks. The beat is strong, the chrous is phenomenal, and it just builds up as it moves along.<br />All in all, \\"Stripped\\" is one of the most amazing female albums in a long time. Christina blossoms into a beautiful flower with this album, her real personality giving her musical talents much more credit than her previous manufactured facade was. Every song is a joy to listen to. You push the beats, the controversy, and the advertising aside, and you will see what the album is: Christina opening her mouth and screaming: \\"I'm me--love it or leave it, I'm happy with who I am.\\"

B00006C79E|4.0|St Etienne are not as famous as they should be, but they sure have some of the fans they deserve.  Looking over what's already been posted on Amazon, it is striking how many reviewers in different countries deeply appreciate the Etienne method.  <br />After the sublime taste of Good Humor, a top ten album for the 1990s, I think many of us found it hard to fathom Sound of Water in 2000.  It was as much our problem as theirs.  They just went off to another minimalist place that was a bit harder for us to follow.  <br />Sometimes reminiscent of the Tiger Bay sound, Finisterre is a subtle and exciting musical trip.  Completely derivative, absolutely original, rigorously intellectual, effortlessly poppy, all at the same time.  Just your average Etienne album really.<br />If Sound of Water left any doubts, this one stamps them as one of the very greatest bands of the past decade.  They are as contemporary as they were in 1991, when that nostalgic riff from She's the One first captured my heart.  No mean feat when most outstanding bands tend to burn out in their first five years.  <br />Perhaps they remain underrated because of their seeming obsession with the surface of pop iconography, or the apparent superficiality of Sarah Cracknell's photogenic looks, but St Etienne are to be revered as pop savants.  Roll on the return visit to Australia.
